speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: -- and if you've got the metal to temperature of the gas temperature, you would end up -- it would creep and, you know, it wouldn't work.  So you're trying to get as much temperature in the turbine as possible without overheating the metal components.

text: Sir, before we move into your file in this matter, I did want to follow up. The project you did with the Solar Turbine, we were talking about the analysis you did on the various components and making sure they all worked together, just from a quick Internet search, it looks like predominantly turbine blades are made of stainless steel, titanium and nickel alloys. Do you recall what the turbines on the Solar Turbine project -- was that the name of the company?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Solar Turbine, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- whether the turbine blades on the Solar Turbine project, which of those materials it was made from?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: I don't recall, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it your testimony that all of the various components in that turbine, whether it was the blades, the rod, the combustion box, you know, everything involving that turbine, that they were all made from the same material?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: No.  I didn't -- I said they were made from compatible materials.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what's your definition of compatible materials?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: A compatible material is one that has -- that when heated, will, even if there's some amount of differential expansion, it will be within acceptable limits, and if you check the overstress, the fatigue, all the other components of the design, you can make it work. In the case of the turbine wheels, typically, the blades are made out of a different material because they have to be higher strength and they have to be creep resistant, and they don't weld them in. They use what's called a fir tree.  It's a machine, an end on the blade that the profile looks sort of like a fir tree, and then a similar -- a female hole is built into the blade -- I mean into the disc to hold them, and you slide them together and press them.  That way you don't have to weld them.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So that you have a lot of stress created by the high-speed spinning of the turbine blades?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: The combination of high-speed spinning plus -- that gives you centrical forces, plus you're heating it at a high temperature.  You know, the hotter you can get the gas to go through there, the more efficient the turbine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: And so it's a combination of you want these things to be spinning as fast as possible and as hot as possible, but you don't want them to grow to the point where they touch the outer rim of the -- because that's when you break a blade.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yeah.  Nobody wants that.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: All hell breaks loose at that point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you indicated that there are probably -- more likely than not, there were different types of materials within the Solar Turbine turbine that you worked on, and you were wanting to make sure -- and even though they likely had different thermal coefficients of expansion, that they need to be within reasonable accommodation, or I forget -- what was your --
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: They have to be compatible under the temperature excursion that you expect.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.  But you talked about the thermal expansion coefficients themselves being within a reasonable range of one another or something to that effect. Do you recall what you had told me?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: I don't recall the exact words.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But you understand the concept I'm talking about?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Yeah.  For example, if you use stainless steels or if you use Inconel, Inconel gives you higher temperature properties, doesn't have as much creep at high temperature, but it's so much nickel -- it has more nickel in it than, say, the high nickel carbon stainless steels, but they'll have a similar coefficient expansion.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is the magnitude of difference in thermal expansion coefficient that you would view as reasonable between two materials for them to be used together in a high-temperature environment?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Well, it depends on the temperature.  The expansion is a product of the alpha, which is the coefficient of thermal expansion times the temperature difference between cold and hot. So if you got a motor that's sitting there at room temperature and you heat it up to, say, 1500 degrees or something, it's going to expand so that if -- for example, if you use a carbon steel, it has a much different coefficient of expansion than stainless steel and so you'll have a differential expansion.  And the bigger the temperature increase, the more strain you will incur at that interface.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you say it's going to depend on the temperature and other factors. What are all the factors you want to consider when determining whether the use of two materials with different thermal expansion coefficients is appropriate for a given application? What are each of the factors?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: The --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Incomplete hypothetical, vague and ambiguous.
speaker: MR. JARCHI

text: I can answer it, though, Rob.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It's just a matter of letting me get my objections on before you answer.
speaker: MR. JARCHI

text: I apologize if I --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No problem.  Try to wait.
speaker: MR. JARCHI

text: But, yes, first of all, a lot of it will depend on the geometry that you're dealing with.  But primarily, when you're using two different materials with different coefficients of expansion, the trick is to maintain a balance between the amount of temperature increase you have and the difference in the alpha, or coefficient of thermal expansion. So if you just take two materials and weld them together, a linear piece of material like a plate, and you weld it together along the seam, the stresses are proportionate to E, assuming they have the same modulus, times the difference in alpha, alpha 1 minus alpha 2, times the temperature increased, delta T.  So the stress is E alpha, difference, delta T. And so if you can maintain that thermal stress within limits, then that will tell you how much temperature rise you can afford for given two materials that are being welded together.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are there any -- are there any constraints on the use of that -- that equation in terms of looking at the differential of the thermal expansion properties?  Can you just increase the temperature without limit and still determine the thermal expansion properties of the two separate materials proportionally without limit as to the amount of stress each one is seeing?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: I'm not sure I understand your question, but could you rephrase it?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yeah.  You said you're balancing the temperature and the thermal expansion differences looking at the stress. If you exceed the ultimate stress capability for one material or the other, is that going to have an impact on the use of the equation that you've just referenced?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Vague and ambiguous, incomplete hypothetical.
speaker: MR. JARCHI

text: You said "sure." How would it?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: The equation I gave --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Hold on.  Sorry.  Same objections.  Just skip a beat before you answer, please.
speaker: MR. JARCHI

text: All right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You can go.
speaker: MR. JARCHI

text: Okay.  All right.  Let's go. The -- to answer your question the best I can, the equation that I give you, the strain is equal to alpha delta T.  That's the strain.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: If you exceed the linear elastic properties of the material, you will still get the same amount of strain, but the stress is no longer proportional to the strain. So basically, you could get yielding in the materials, and typically, when you're doing a thermal stress analysis, you have different stress limits that you would use for thermal stress analysis compared to the -- say, just the loading of a part. And according to the ASME code, for example, thermal stresses are categorized as secondary stresses so that you can actually have a range of stress so that even if you yield something on the first part of the cycle, you'll get a -- when it cools down, you'll get a residual stress so that when you heat it up again, you'll go from being in, say, compression to tension so you can get -- the range of stress can be up to twice yield and still be acceptable.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So in layman's terms -- or not layman's, but at least less engineering terms -- when you're talking about yield, are you talking about some form of plastic deformation of the material?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Sure.  If you -- if you take a bar, a tensile specimen and pull on it, by Hooke's law, you'll get a linear relationship of a displacement versus the load.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And once that plastic deformation or permanent deformation is --
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Once you reach the yield point, now you're -- you will no longer get an increase in stress that's proportional to the strain.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: That's yielding. But with thermal stresses, it's okay sometimes to yield, because when it cools down, you'll get a residual stress that will be beneficial to you, so on the next cycle you'll get a different -- you won't be yielding on the second go-around.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And it can even change between tension and compression?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Yeah.  And of course one of the complicating factors is that, number one, if you look at the allowable -- if you look at the yields, the yield at high temperature is usually lower, considerably lower than the yield at low temperature. Secondly, if you're up to around 1200, 1400 degrees, you're going to get creep, so you think you're going to have a residual stress, but what happens is that residual stress creeps out at the high temperature. So when you start dealing with this thermal stress analysis, it is -- it's not -- it's not a simple -- it's not a simple case.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Okay.  To get light to come out, you've got to have a pretty good size hole.  There could be --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How big a hole is it required for light to pass through?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: I don't think he's finished his answer. So could you please finish your answer?
speaker: MR. JARCHI

text: The hole there could have been hairline cracked in all of them, and if they were small cracks, they might not have shown up. There could be partial cracks in all of them and you wouldn't see light coming through there.  But in every case, if you continued to use those heat exchangers, they could have resulted in a complete breach. So if you wanted to do a real inspection, you should have done something like a dye penetrant check, which means that you should put dye penetrant liquid on there and then use some type of a black light to determine if you have a crack. So in my humble opinion, the method used to determine a failed heat exchanger was extremely crude and wouldn't necessarily turn up all the failures.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: So therefore, your answer to my question -- to answer your question, do I think that there could be more heat exchangers or all could fail, it's quite possible.

speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How big has the hole got to be for light to pass through it?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: It depends on the crack shape.  If you have a V-shaped crack, light won't pass through it because it doesn't reflect very well.  In many cases, you will have a crack that is open whenever it's hot and closes up when it cools off, and you wouldn't see that crack except by dye penetrant methodology.

text: What's your understanding of the operation and purpose of pressure switches installed on the subject oven?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Vague and ambiguous, incomplete hypothetical.
speaker: MR. JARCHI

text: My understanding of the pressure switch is that the pressure switch measures the pressure inside of the combustion chamber, or when you turn the blower on for the burner, the fan is supposed to start up. You have a small fan motor.  It's an eighth of a horsepower, or something like that, not a very big motor, and it runs a squirrel cage fan, and it blows air into the combustion chamber. It's a big cylinder.  It's like 12 inches in diameter, if I remember, in that neighborhood, and when you blow air into this combustion chamber, you will build up a certain pressure.  The reason is, because there's a back pressure of pushing air through the heat exchanger, it takes quite a bit of pressure differential to blow air through this thing. So as you're blowing air into the combustion chamber, you will increase the pressure in the combustion chamber with respect to the ambient condition, and your pressure switches, if I recall, were set so that if you're between 1 and 1.4, or something like that, inches of water, then -- then the computer that's in the heater, modular combustion blower, that computer recognizes that the fan is on.  That's how it knows that air is coming into the combustion chamber. And the pressure switch then is really just a device so that whenever the pressure differential reaches a certain amount, then it -- it is taught to believe that the fan is running, and so now it knows that air should be being blown into the combustion chamber. And that's all it does.  It just recognizes that there are -- that there is a blower blowing into the combustion chamber.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Is the -- do you know whether the purpose of that is to ensure that you don't ignite the burner with an overly-rich mixture; that you make sure make sure that there's plenty of air blowing into the burner, as you say, before you ignite the burner?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Objection; vague and ambiguous and calls for speculation, depending on who the -- just leave it at that.
speaker: MR. JARCHI

text: Well, my understanding of it is basically twofold. Number one, it's blowing air into the combustion chamber, and you don't want to start putting gas in there before you have air flowing through it. And the second function of the pressure switch and the blower is to evacuate all products of combustion or whatever's left in the heat exchanger and start out with clean, fresh air, theoretically, in through the heat exchanger and all the way up through the exhaust duct.  And that's why you run it for 30 -- 30-something seconds before you try to ignite the burner.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  That's what they call the purge cycle?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: You could call it a purge cycle.

And so you can actually start to see combustion products leak out of the door at these leaking areas where they're not sealed properly without having a great deal of increased internal pressure.  A few inches of water will do it.

If you have a good Swagelok design and you have expanded the inner piece of tubing against the outer piece of tubing and you have some residual compression there, it will be pretty tight and you'll get a very, very small amount of leakage under pressure, similarly with a hairline crack. But hairline cracks grow into big cracks, and they end up growing completely where their tubes are three-quarters of an inch missing.  So that's a -- it's a different problem altogether.  It's not the same.  You can't say A equals B.

speaker: MR. CROSS

text: What happens in -- first of all, this is normally what is referred to as low cycle fatigue, okay?  The failure of that mode is what we call low cycle fatigue. My calculations indicate that every cycle of this heat exchanger produced stresses that were greater than the ultimate stress.  That doesn't necessarily mean you get a crack on the first cycle, but it means that if you don't -- you don't go very many cycles until you start to fatigue the material and start to get an incipient crack. Once that crack initiates, it may not go all the way through the weld.  Typically, it does not.  So you're going to have more cycles happening until the crack goes all the way through the weld, and now you have a breach in the heat exchanger. Initially, that will be a small crack and you won't get much of an emission through there. But a small crack grows, especially it's going to start to grow faster because you have combustion products going into that crack and now you're attacking the crack on all surfaces. So initially, you're only attacking the inside of the tube, but after you grow a crack in it, now you're attacking the whole crack all the way through. So the question that -- what I would have to determine is -- I believe I could calculate the number of cycles to initiate or at least approximate that.  I could calculate the number of cracks to grow it all the way through. The thing that makes it more difficult is to determine how fast the gap grows, and then that depends on how much oxidation you're getting in the tube and whether there's a flame present at that point.  So it gets a little hairy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: I was trying to make those calculations, but -- they're doable, but I guess to go back after this longwinded answer, I believe you will get crack initiation and crack propagation fairly soon, within like a year of operating it.

text: Again, I don't know that, and the reason is, this problem of cracking and carbon monoxide production is very interrelated.  As you've seen from our test, changing the amount of air in the burner airflow will change the amount of carbon monoxide that's generated so that as this crack grows, you change the air fuels mixture, and so you may be developing very high carbon monoxide at some point as the tube continues to fail and the gaps get bigger and bigger. So that's what I mean by it's interrelated. the carbon monoxide production depends on how much -- on the air-fuel mixture.  The more -- the more you change that, you can have very high variations in carbon monoxide production.  So that's why I can't answer that question.

text: Are you going to talk about any other aspect of the design of the heat exchanger besides the use of aluminized carbon steel tubes joined to stainless steel?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Same objection; vague and ambiguous.
speaker: MR. JARCHI

text: Well, I will say that when I reviewed the design of the heat exchanger, I found it defective in many ways.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  What is each aspect of the heat exchanger that you find is defective?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Calls for a narrative as reflected in Exhibit 6, vague and ambiguous, incomplete hypothetical.
speaker: MR. JARCHI

text: Okay.  Having designed many heat exchangers over the years, I looked at this design and I can see a number of things that are defective about it as far as the design goes. Number one, the -- and of course the most important is the use of dissimilar metals, welding them together when you're going to have a high heat excursion. Number two, using boxes on the ends of the tube.  When you run the gas flow into a wall, flat wall, you are -- you're losing a tremendous amount of energy.  You're dissipating the kinetic energy of the airflow through the heat exchanger.  It hits the wall and becomes a stagnation condition.  It has to reaccelerate through the next layer of tubes going the other way.  It hits that wall.  You lose pressure back and forth, back and forth. So your pressure drop to that heat exchanger is going to be much higher than it could be if you used some kind of a return bend.  Almost all heat exchangers have return bends rather than flat walls. The next point that was a terrible part of the design is that these tubes are inline.  If you're going to get decent heat transfer, you need to have staggered raise of tubes.  Staggered raise of tubes greatly enhance the air-to-air heat transfer between the heat exchanger and the two cross loads. You have the air flowing across these tubes coming from the -- from the oven convection, and then when you have inline tubes like this.  The tubes on the farthest side away from the air direction are going to be very ineffective in transferring their heat to the convection air. And then finally, the most important thing, probably, is that this heat exchanger is a safety component. In other industries, such as the nuclear industry, we often have a primary side and a secondary side.  Here the primary side is the gas going through that's heated.  The secondary side is the convection air flowing across there. The key to this heat exchanger is that you don't want to mix those two together.  You do not want to have combustion products going into the bake chamber so that the heat exchanger is a safety-related piece of equipment, and as such, should be treated as such.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So let me first ask you.  You had a throw-off comment there that you've designed many heat exchangers. Can you identify for me each heat exchanger you've designed over your career?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Sure.  I started off my career in the nuclear business.  I've designed heat exchangers for the Navy nuclear program for submarines and aircraft carriers. Next, after I finished my Ph.D., I went to work for Westinghouse as a consultant on the Clinch River breeder reactor.  Then I designed heat exchangers for sodium -- sodium heat exchangers. After that, I went and spent a lot of time in the commercial nuclear business designing heat exchangers. Then I progressed to the refining business and worked in the refining business designing literally thousands of heat exchangers.  Let's make it hundreds.  I don't want to sound too old.  But I had contracts with ARCO, other companies, refineries where I rated and re-rated all the heat exchangers in their -- in their refineries. What else.  Those are the major ones.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So the Navy program and Westinghouse, you were working with heat exchangers involved with nuclear reactors?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: They were.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And then in terms of commercial heat exchangers, you were looking at heat exchangers in refineries, primarily with ARCO?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: No, probably ten different refineries.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And how are heat exchangers used in refineries?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Heat exchangers are used in refineries to transfer heat from a hot fluid or to a cold fluid, and they call -- in some cases, they call them regenerators, because when you have -- when you produce diesel gasoline, it's often produced at high temperatures, 1800 degrees, and rather than lose that heat, you will go through a heat exchanger and cool the product, the diesel or the gas, down to a much lower temperature.  And you're using that heat to heat up something else that you would have in a reaction.  So refineries are very good about not throwing away heat.  Heat costs money.  And so basically, that's what heat exchangers are used for. In this case, it's very similar.  You're heating the heat exchanger with natural gas and you're using that natural gas heated air to transfer the heat to the bakery air.  So it's just a matter of using the heat -- heating value of the natural gas for baking bread.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So I want to go through the various defects you identified.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The first one was that the use of dissimilar metals in an environment of high heat excursion. In your mind, that's what led to the failure of the welds and the breach of the heat exchanger in this case; correct?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So that alleged defect is directly related to the failure mode of the heat exchanger, in your opinion?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, the second one you talked about was the use of boxes on the end of the tubes rather than a return bin type design, and the problem there was you have stagnation where the flow has to stop completely and then reverse itself, and that leads to a pressure drop at the end of -- or at the termination of each tube, essentially?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So ultimately, what you're dealing with, then, is the flue gas is moving through the heat exchanger under lower velocity or pressure because it has to stop at the end of each box?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: And you're not -- you're not -- you have pressure drop through the heat exchanger so that you don't have as good a flow out the stack.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And the problem with that is because the pressure is lower and it's not moving as quickly, you're dissipating heat and you're losing heat, so it makes the heat exchanger less efficient?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Is there anything about the box ends as opposed to a return bin that in your mind facilitated the failure of the heat exchanger, or is it just an efficiency defect?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: No.  The fact that you're welding a tube into a flat plate which forms the box is the worst configuration. The flat plate is very rigid in that plane, whereas, the tube wants to expand due to thermal expansion, and so therefore, you get the maximum amount of stiffness preventing radial expansion as opposed to if you have a cylinder into a 180-degree bend, it wouldn't give you that.  Even if they were dissimilar metals, the two cylinders are much more compatible than a flat plate and a cylinder.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So the first thing we talked about was the use of dissimilar metals that are going to expand differently in comparison to temperature. This is a different aspect that looks at the geometry of the pipe coming into the box, and the stresses imposed by that geometry you're saying with a different shape of the return bin instead of a box, you would reduce the stresses imposed by that connection?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Then the third item you talked about was the use of inline tubes as opposed to some sort of staggered matrix or configuration. Again, is that alleged defect, in your opinion, something that contributed to the failure mode of the subject heat exchanger or something that again just reduces efficiency?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: It -- I don't think it contributes to the failure mode.  I can't think of any way it would, but it will definitely reduce the efficiency of the heat exchanger.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: And probably make it larger than it needs to be.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then the last item you talked about was you view the heat exchanger as a safety component that -- and I guess, then, your opinion is going to be that you should make sure that that doesn't fail, or what is your opinion with respect to why it's a defect, given that it's a safety component?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Well, it's a safety-related component. That means that you can't afford to have to breach that containment. You see it all the time in the nuclear business.  You have water with radiation in it compared to fresh water on the other side. You see it in refineries where you're cooling two different fluids, and you -- and they don't mix well.  You don't want to mix the two components.  Sometimes you can get an explosion if you do.  So all of those things.  It's safety related in that if you get a breach in one, it could cause an explosion or something bad could happen.
speaker: THE WITNESS

Abrasion causes you to lose material on something. The heat exchanger doesn't have any abrasion.  There's nothing grinding material off causing material to be lost.  They should last forever.

But it has to do with the life expectation and the consequences of failure, because the risk and the consequence of failure is one of the things that you have to take into account when you're doing design, and you cannot have a safety-related component that fails 27 percent of the time, okay?  It's unacceptable.

But other components, like your radiator in your car which is a heat exchanger, I've never seen anybody expect their radiator to fail before the tires go. And so just to put that in perspective, that little 8 horsepower motor that you have at the blower, it develops somewhere between 1 and 1.4 inches of water, and so even if it's only 1 inch of water and this is .08, you know, we're talking about a factor of 10 or something on the difference. You're pulling air up with this draft inducer; you're pushing air up with the blower. Another way I thought about it is that if you want to know how much vacuum .04 inches of water is, think about putting a straw into a McDonald's and sucking on it until the water rises 04 inches, which is the thickness of a credit card.  That didn't strike me as enough vacuum to do very much. So I looked at that and I said, "Well, the fan on the" -- "on the blower is producing a hell of a lot more pressure at the inlet to the heat exchanger than this draft inducer is causing back in up at the stack.

So if this little small vacuum up at the stack is trying to pull something from the bottom of the heat exchanger, the inlet area where the burner is, it's got a hell of a job. text: Overpressure vent primarily is there because during the baking cycle, occasionally you want to call for steam in the bake chamber.  And when that happens, you have a water supply that sprays water on these steel spherical balls that are part of the -- part of the mechanism of the oven, and when you spray water on those balls, which are hotter than the boiling point of water, they flash into steam, and when you flash water into steam, you get a volume increase of about 998 to 1.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And so this is one mechanism of allowing that excessive pressure we talked about when steam's injected into the bake chamber to escape the bake chamber, other than --

And one of the kind of interesting things is, since this stuff is probably going to be hotter than what's in the bake chamber, it's going to force -- it's going to go up and it will force the cooler air inside the bake chamber out the vent here. They're designing for numbers up to 1600 degrees in his testimony. But let's just say they're 1400 degrees. We'll give it the benefit of the doubt.  I also believe that you're going to have an overpressure there forcing that hot air into the bake chamber, because I believe the pressure in the heat exchanger will be higher than the pressure in the bake chamber.  Because as you pointed out, the bake chamber is vented to the atmosphere, so it's going to maintain about atmospheric pressure; whereas, we know the combustor is going to increase the pressure.  So you're going to be blowing hot combustion products into the bake chamber. Logically, they rise to the top of the bake chamber, and as they fill the bake chamber, you're going to be pushing the colder air that might be more nearly atmospheric conditions out the vent, because it vents from the bottom.

text: That's my understanding.  That's what I think happened, yes.

text: Okay.  And you've talked about that a little bit a couple times today.  You used the term "low cycle fatigue" and you referenced that I think one other time earlier today and you said the low cycle fatigue is being caused by the cyclical stresses imposed on the weld. How are you using the term "low circle fatigue"?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: If you look at a fatigue curve for any of these materials, what you find is that it's usually a logarithmic curve and you have a vertical axis which is alternating stress.  You have a horizontal axis which is logarithm of the number of cycles. And if you have low cycle fatigue, you will find that you'll start to develop a crack within a few hundred cycles, usually, and that high cycle fatigue can take you all the way out to a million cycles without cracking. So the curve is -- again, it's a logarithmic curve that starts of high stress because you can take a -- for a few cycles, you can take a high stress cycle, but if you want it to last a hundred thousand cycles, you got to reduce that alternating stress cycle.  If you want it to last forever, you've got to have a very low alternating stress, and that's the nature of fatigue curves. And so anything that fails in the very early stages after a few hundred cycles, say, that would be a low cycle fatigue.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  But you haven't attempted to quantify and put a specific number of cycles on the failure for this particular design; rather, it's the idea that the stress is imposed by each cycle and above the ultimate yield strengths, so you would not expect it to last into the high cycle range?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: It won't last long, because each time you heat it up and cool it down, you are inducing a large strain. And it turns out that fatigue is actually more driven by strain than it is stress, and when you're doing fatigue tests to determine how long a metal will last, you typically use a strain test rather than a stress test, except for very high cycle like in an aircraft design.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. text: Okay.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: When you are -- when you first start up the fan, there's no flame, and so you get a fairly small pressure drop through the heat exchanger because you have low flow.  You don't have a lot of volume of air going through the heat exchanger. When you have low flow, your pressure drops pretty small, and you don't see the resistance.  The pressure drop is related to low velocity. In other words, the more air you try to push through a given hole, the more pressure it takes to do it, as you can -- I mean it doesn't take a genius to figure that out. So I wanted to get a feeling for how much the pressure would increase whenever we kicked on the burner, okay?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: And so when you first start up the blower, you just have ambient air going into the blower. You try to light this.  You turn on the gas.  You get your igniter, and all of a sudden you get a flame. You're putting 318,000 BTUs in this thing. That's a lot of energy, okay?  That energy has to go someplace; right?  And where it goes is in expanding the gas.  The amount of gas volume compared to the amount of air volume is pretty low so that you can -- for a first order of assumption, you can just assume that the air you have coming in is going to be converted to hot gas, so that now we get an expansion of that hot gas.  The gas will expand, and it expands a lot between ambient, which may be 70 degrees feeder air, and all of a sudden, that gas is heated up to 1200 degrees or something like that. And I looked up the methane plane temperature.  It's 3452.  Of course, we won't get that hot a gas because we're mixing air with it and it's not going to be complete combustion. So there's a lot of reasons we don't see 3452, but we will see a fairly high temperature. And we know that we have exhaust gases coming out up to 500 degrees, and that's after you've taken the heat out of that gas with your heat exchanger.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: So I'm saying let's just assume that the gas heats up, and I -- for a first cut, I said, "Let's assume it goes up to the max of 1600," which I believe Mills says is kind of an upper limit on his use of stainless steel.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: So if that's what he's saying is the maximum, I'll start out with that in number. So the next thing I do there is say, "Okay, what happens to the gas whenever heated up for an ambient to 1600."  Well, it expands, and it expands a lot, okay?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: And, you know, you've experienced that if you, you know, have a balloon or whatever.  Whenever it gets hot or cold, it changes its size.  This is really expanding the gas. On the other hand, whenever this gas expands and I'm trying to push it through there, it's got to have a higher velocity.  Because I've got X number of cubic feet of gas going through the same area, it's got to go through there faster. Well, the faster it goes through there, the higher the pressure. So when I put it under pressure, it actually gets smaller again, so I got two things competing.  The heating expands the gas, but if I increase the pressure, it compresses the gas.  So it's not a simple problem to figure out. So what I did was to go through there, and I used these basic equations of fluid flow.  One is mass continuity, M dot.  That's the mass flow rate. Row V1a1 is equal to Row 2 V2a2 on Page 1, and I know what the initial density of the gas is, .074 pounds per cubic feet, and that gives me a starting point. Now, and then I -- I look up the density of air, and that's on the last page, air density in pounds per cubic feet, at different temperatures. And so I applied it for different temperatures and different pressures.  So you can see from this, if you look carefully, you'll see that the density varies with the pressure in terms of atmosphere; in other words, if I double the pressure, the density goes -- goes up by a factor of 2.  If I triple the pressure, and that's one of the basic laws of physics, Boyle's Law or Charles Law or somebody's law.  So if it's a law, it's got to be right. So now I have the situation where I have -- I've got an idea of how much more volume I've got to push through there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: That tells me I can calculate the new velocities.  And then I also know that the higher the velocity, I'm going to get a pressure increase because I've got to push harder to get the gas to go through. So now higher pressure compresses the gas, and I'll have a tradeoff, and so I want to use these equations to determine what that tradeoff is, and that's what I've done here.  I used those equations and I used something called Bernoulli's law. Bernoulli's law says that the rho v squared over 2g -- that's velocity squared -- plus the pressure, plus the head, is equal to a constant. So what it tells me is I can trade off static pressure for kinetic energy, and so then I used that equation, combined that with my other pressure ratio equations, and I find out that after I go through this that the pressure will be the ratio -- will increase by the ratio of the two velocities, the velocity before I pressurize -- before I burn it, and then the pressure with the velocity after the combustor turns off. And the whole point of doing this is to find out whenever I hit the -- turn on the gas and I start blowing hot air through this thing, am I going have a higher pressure at this failed area than I would before, and it turns out it's a linear relationship with the velocity. So, yes, the answer is I will have a much higher pressure at those failed tubes when I'm burning it than I will whenever I don't have combustion going on.

text: No.

text: Okay.  What's a stagnation pressure?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: If you have air and you're blowing it against a flat surface like we are here, the air will be moving along at a given velocity.  All of a sudden, when it hits the wall, it has to stop, okay? And I can use Bernoulli's equation, as I did down here on Page 2, to calculate what the pressure would be when I have no velocity, and that is the stagnation pressure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So that's the pressure at the point where the velocity of the gas drops to zero?
speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Correct, before it turns around and goes the other way.

speaker: MR. CROSS

text: I know that at the point where these tubes are failed, you're essentially at zero velocity, because the air has to stop going to the left and go back to the right.  So it has no velocity, or very little velocity.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. CROSS

speaker: MR. CROSS

text: Well, there's a couple of bases. First of all, you have a very low amount of air that you're moving through the vent and in the best conditions. Secondly, I've designed -- I've designed hoods before, and I don't think this hood design is -- from an engineering standpoint, it appears to be very poor. It looks like to me from all I can figure in the ones that I've seen that it's open underneath the hood. The way you design a hood is that you have a fan causing a draft.  Then you put a flat plate inside the hood that only has about an inch gap all the way around.  And by doing that, you increase the velocity around the edges of the hood to what we call the capture velocity.  So all the fumes that would come up under the hood would be sucked into the hood because they couldn't get out without passing through the capture velocity. If you have a hood that just has a big opening up there with no plate in it to increase the airflow at the periphery, you don't capture very much of the fumes, they'll go around there, because the average flow velocity is 1.6 feet per second, which is about one mile per hour.  I walk three miles an hour, at least, so that's about a third of the walking speed.
